docs.abstract: Nothing sounds quite so sensible or healthy as ‘reform’ — whether its ultimate goal is to improve society or, these days, to stop trying.
docs.snippet: Nothing sounds quite so sensible or healthy as ‘reform’ — whether its ultimate goal is to improve society or, these days, to stop trying.
docs.lead_paragraph: When we elect politicians to office, it’s with the expectation (or at least the hope) that they will do something meant to improve our lives. Presumably this improvement will require change, the correction of past mistakes or persistent injustices — a process known, in its most benevolent guise, as “reform.” In personal life, reform means a brave step toward self-improvement and purification; nobody reforms himself into becoming an alcoholic. It’s much the same in the public sphere: a promise to fix what’s wrong with the body politic, usually through sober bipartisan policymaking. The process, in theory, goes only one way — onward into a brighter, better future.

headline.main: When ‘Reform’ Means a Process of Elimination

docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what a birth mother owes her son’s adoptive mother.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what a birth mother owes her son’s adoptive mother.
docs.lead_paragraph: We adopted our son about 25 years ago, when “open adoptions” were still a novel idea. We were fortunate enough to meet and spend time with our son’s birth parents and be present at his birth. The parameters of our adoption agreement were solid, albeit tinged with some regret on the part of our son’s birth mother.

headline.main: What if Our Son’s Birth Mother Wants a Relationship With Him — but Not Us?
headline.print_headline: What if Our Son’s Birth Mother Wants A Relationship With Him — But Not Us?

docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on forming a relationship with the child you gave away and the practice of making marriage a reparation for rape.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on forming a relationship with the child you gave away and the practice of making marriage a reparation for rape.
docs.lead_paragraph: Many decades ago, I gave up a child in a private adoption. At that time, I was advised never to search for my child (and not even to note the name on the papers), and I was assured that my identity would likewise be kept secret.

headline.main: What if I Don’t Want to See the Child I Gave Up for Adoption?
headline.print_headline: What if I Don’t Want to See the Child I Gave Up For Adoption?

docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on inequality in college admissions, inequality in parents’ wills and more.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on inequality in college admissions, inequality in parents’ wills and more.
docs.lead_paragraph: I am currently a senior in high school and am lucky enough to have been admitted to a prestigious private university. I’m strongly considering attending this school because of its excellent academics and the other opportunities it offers me, and because my family can afford it.

headline.main: Should I Go to a College I’ve Been Admitted to as a Legacy?
headline.print_headline: Should I Go To a College I’ve Been Admitted to As a Legacy?

docs.abstract: Images of violence can desensitize us, but they can also remind us of our common bond.
docs.snippet: Images of violence can desensitize us, but they can also remind us of our common bond.
docs.lead_paragraph: A photograph of a group of suffering people: We look at them, and from the sadness of their expressions and gestures, we know something awful has happened. But finding out exact details, through the photograph alone, is more difficult. Who these sufferers are, why they suffer, who or what caused the suffering and what ought to be done about it: These are entirely more complex questions, questions hard to answer only by looking at the photograph.

headline.main: What Does It Mean to Look at This?
headline.print_headline: What Does It Mean to Look at This?
